bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, February 26, 1954

div1.p: Hench thanks Mrs. Carroll for allowing him to examine James Carroll's papers. He requests permission to make copies of additional material.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, February 26, 1954
div1.opener:
February 26, 1954
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Avenue N.E.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mrs. Carroll:
div1.p:
I appreciated so very much your courtesy to me during my recent visit.
I thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity of looking over Doctor Carroll's
data even though I had such a limited opportunity to study it. I hope
that you feel as I do - satisfied that at least a beginning has been
made in the proper study and disposition of this material. I hope also
that the day spent with me was not too tiresome for you and that per-
haps you even enjoyed it a bit. I think it is always helpful to be
able to talk over one's problems with a sympathetic friend. Certainly
you have a very difficult problem to face and I do hope that I can help
in some way. I shall shortly write a little note to your minister but
I want to compose the letter carefully and will not write it hastily.

I am having copied the few photographs which you kindly loaned to me.
I am not treating these in a routine manner but am consulting the head
of our photographic department about them. The photographs are, in my
opinion, most interesting and useful as I have not seen photographs
taken from that particular angle. In one of the photographs there are
two or three little buildings that I am anxious to have show up in the
copy. They are very faint and we may have to photograph them more than
once and indeed we may have to retouch it; however it will be done by
experts and if our local man cannot do it, I will consult the Eastman
Kodak Store in Minneapolis. Rest assured that these photographs will
be safe in my hands and returned to you. I will not only return the
originals to you (unless you later decide to present them to the
yellow fever museum of which I have told you so much) but I will send
you copies of these so that not only you but your husband's two sisters
may have them if you wish to send them. I will send them all to you.

I asked you whether you had a copy of Dr. Howard Kelly's book on Walter
Reed and yellow fever. Certainly there was none in the trunks and I do
think you ought to have one. I have an extra copy and am happy indeed
to send it to you by separate post.

I am of course anxious to return to Washington or to make some arrange-
ments which will be satisfactory to you with regard to photostating all
of the material in the one box with the data of greater importance. I
hope to get to Washington some time later this year, but it will not be
until fall at least. Would you be willing, meanwhile, to let me do the
following: One of my former Mayo Clinic secretaries, Miss Dorma Schnurr,
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
- 2 -
February 26, 1954
has lived in Washington for several years. She is a very able person
and, incidentally, takes shorthand. Would you be willing to let me
have her make the arrangements with a photostat company, making a date
to suit your mutual convenience and then would you let her come for you,
take you down town and together you two could be there while the photo-
stats are being made. Or if you do not want to bother, Miss Schnurr
could come to your home, make a quick catalog of the material in the
one box and take it herself to the photostat company down town, re-
turning it the same day if the photostatic company can do it all in
one day.

I am so happy for your cooperation in this matter because our purposes
are the same - to show the world just exactly what Doctor Carroll did,
and without access to the material you have, I know that my story about
Doctor Carroll's activities would be incomplete.

When I catch my breath, I will send you a rough list of the material we
found in the trunks with extra copies which you may or may not give to
your lawyer and to Mr. Carroll's two sisters, depending on your own
decision in the matter. I will not correspond with his sisters or
with your lawyer about this matter, although in the near future I
would like to send to your lawyer two of my reprints so that he may
see how very interested I am in the yellow fever work. I do not want
to delay sending you the Kelly book until the list of material in the
trunks is finished or the photographs copied. These will be along
in due time.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
